title: NYC to spend $1M on ads promoting rent freeze
text:
The campaign will also remind people that the freeze is only for one-year leases on rent regulated apartments from Oct. 2015 through Sept. 30, 2016. The city is spending $1 million on ads promoting something no rent-paying New Yorker would likely ever forget — the recently enacted rent freeze.
Mayor de Blasio will spend the money on newspaper, subway and radio ads to raise awareness of the freeze, his office said.
The campaign will also remind people that the freeze is only for one-year leases on rent regulated apartments from Oct. 2015 through Sept. 30, 2016.
Two-year leases on rent regulated apartments have a 2% hike — and the campaign will highlight that in some case that might actually be a better deal because it’s unclear what next year’s hike will be.
The Rent Stabilization Association — which represents 25,000 landlords — blasted the mayor for the campaign, saying he should spend the money to “feed the poor, house the homeless, and provide rent subsidies to those most in need.”
DE BLASIO LAUNCHES $12.3M PLAN TO HELP TENANTS FIGHTING OFF EVICTIONS GET LEGAL AIDE
City Hall said the cost of the campaign is small compared with others, including anti-smoking initiatives. “We want to make sure that tenants give both the one-year freeze and very low two-year increase a hard look,” said spokesman Wiley Norvell.
